commit_message:
Add unstable tag to test with intermittent failures

The test 'test_create_extend_and_write' started failing
intermittently when run under CIFS protocol. This change adds
a unstable test tag to the test to the result will be ignored
when it fails again.

Closes-Bug: #1903922
Change-Id: Ic5527243c0b08dbbfbc849a7c2e79ff927c23098

commit_message:
Add tests for only_host scheduler hint.

Test for only_host scheduler hint added and guarded by multiple backends
check. Validated for version >= 2.67 since scheduler_hints are added in
that version.

Depends-on: I603434cac246e2c0946672d3f0fe469ed5423fa4
Depends-on: I2e6d8709fc02df16622bdc910127fa489835db38
Change-Id: I14045d3816f80841508d9e94dbe48addc252590f

added_lines: # Copyright 2021 Cloudification GmbH # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from tempest import config from tempest.lib import decorators from testtools import testcase as tc from manila_tempest_tests.tests.api import base from manila_tempest_tests import utils CONF = config.CONF class SharesSchedulerHintsAdminTest(base.BaseSharesAdminTest): @classmethod def skip_checks(cls): super(SharesSchedulerHintsAdminTest, cls).skip_checks() if not CONF.share.multi_backend: raise cls.skipException("Manila multi-backend is disabled.") elif len(CONF.share.backend_names) < 2: raise cls.skipException("For running multi-backend tests required" " two names in config. Skipping.") elif any(not name for name in CONF.share.backend_names): raise cls.skipException("Share backend names can not be empty. " "Skipping.") utils.check_skip_if_microversion_not_supported('2.65') @classmethod def resource_setup(cls): super(SharesSchedulerHintsAdminTest, cls).resource_setup() # create share type cls.share_type = cls.create_share_type() cls.share_type_id = cls.share_type['id'] # create share cls.share_a = cls.create_share(share_type_id=cls.share_type_id) @decorators.idempotent_id('54f4dea7-890e-443b-aea5-f6108da893f0') @tc.attr(base.TAG_POSITIVE, base.TAG_API_WITH_BACKEND) def test_only_host_scheduler_hint_in_share_creation(self): share_a = self.admin_shares_v2_client.get_share( self.share_a['id'])['share'] backend_a = share_a['host'] scheduler_hint = {"only_host": "%s" % backend_a} # create share with hint share_b = self.create_share(share_type_id=self.share_type_id, scheduler_hints=scheduler_hint, cleanup_in_class=False) # get backend of share share_b = self.admin_shares_v2_client.get_share( share_b['id'])['share'] backend_b = share_b['host'] # verify same backends self.assertEqual(backend_a, backend_b)

subject: Complete phase-1 of RBAC community-wide goal
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2022-02-18 09:29:23.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/220aca8b5e25b22cde72096b2e7f6fa91eec2207', 'message': "Complete phase-1 of RBAC community-wide goal

After moving the nova APIs policy as per the new guidlines
where system scoped token will be only allowed to access
system level APIs and will not be allowed any operation
on project level APIs. With that we do not need below
base rules (who have hardcoded 'system_scope:all' check_str):
- system_admin_api
- system_reader_api
- system_admin_or_owner
- system_or_project_reader

At this stage (phase-1 target), we allow below roles as targeted
in phase-1 [1]
1. ADMIN(this is System Administrator with scope_type 'system'
when scope enabled otherwise legacy admin)
2. PROJECT_ADMIN
3. PROJECT_MEMBER
4. PROJECT_READER
 & below one specific to nova
5. PROJECT_READER_OR_ADMIN (to allow system admin and project reader
to list flavor extra specs)

This complete the phase-1 of RBAC community-wide goal[2] for nova.

[1] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/consistent-and-secure-rbac.html#how-operator
[2] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/consistent-and-secure-rbac.html#yoga-timeline-7th-mar-2022

Partial implement blueprint policy-defaults-refresh-2

on project level APIs. With that we do not need below
base rules (who have hardcoded 'system_scope:all' check_str):
- system_admin_api
- system_reader_api
- system_admin_or_owner
- system_or_project_reader

At this stage (phase-1 target), we allow below roles as targeted
in phase-1 [1]
1. ADMIN(this is System Administrator with scope_type 'system'
when scope enabled otherwise legacy admin)
2. PROJECT_ADMIN
3. PROJECT_MEMBER
4. PROJECT_READER
 & below one specific to nova
5. PROJECT_READER_OR_ADMIN (to allow system admin and project reader
to list flavor extra specs)

This complete the phase-1 of RBAC community-wide goal[2] for nova.

Add release notes too.

[1] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/consistent-and-secure-rbac.html#how-operator
[2] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/consistent-and-secure-rbac.html#yoga-timeline-7th-mar-2022

Partial implement blueprint policy-defaults-refresh-2

commit_message:
Complete phase-1 of RBAC community-wide goal

After moving the nova APIs policy as per the new guidlines
where system scoped token will be only allowed to access
system level APIs and will not be allowed any operation
on project level APIs. With that we do not need below
base rules (who have hardcoded 'system_scope:all' check_str):
- system_admin_api
- system_reader_api
- system_admin_or_owner
- system_or_project_reader

At this stage (phase-1 target), we allow below roles as targeted
in phase-1 [1]
1. ADMIN(this is System Administrator with scope_type 'system'
when scope enabled otherwise legacy admin)
2. PROJECT_ADMIN
3. PROJECT_MEMBER
4. PROJECT_READER
 & below one specific to nova
5. PROJECT_READER_OR_ADMIN (to allow system admin and project reader
to list flavor extra specs)

This complete the phase-1 of RBAC community-wide goal[2] for nova.

Add release notes too.

[1] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/consistent-and-secure-rbac.html#how-operator
[2] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/consistent-and-secure-rbac.html#yoga-timeline-7th-mar-2022

Partial implement blueprint policy-defaults-refresh-2

Change-Id: I075005d13ff6bfe048bbb21d80d71bf1602e4c02
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/66/829866/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: "system_admin_or_owner": "rule:system_admin_api or rule:project_member_api", "system_or_project_reader": "rule:system_reader_api or rule:project_reader_api", "system_admin_api": "role:admin and system_scope:all", "system_reader_api": "role:reader and system_scope:all",

subject: Add reno for unified limits

commit_message:
Add reno for unified limits

This first version should be considered as a preview, that will become
more useable once more of the transition tooling has been implemented.

Given the massive change, it seems prudent to get as much of this into
operators hands as quickly as possible, so we can get some early
feedback.

blueprint unified-limits-nova

Change-Id: I80ccca500d1a2eb8f19b5843a0d0d337c583e104
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/71/715271/15 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- other: - | This release includes work in progress support for Keystone's unified limits. This should not be used in production. It is included so we can collect early feedback from operators around the performance of the new limits system. There is currently no way to export your existing quotas and import them into Keystone. There is also no proxy API to allow you to updated unified limits via Nova APIs. All the update APIs behave as if you are using the noop driver. Note that only ``cores``, ``instances`` and ``ram`` quotas have moved to unified limits. When you enable unified limits, those are configured in Keystone against the Nova endpoint, using the names ``class:VCPU``, ``servers`` and ``class:MEMORY_MB``. All other resources classes requested via flavors are also now supported as unified limits. Note that nova configuration is ignored, as the default limits come from the limits registered for the Nova endpoint in Keystone. All previous quotas other than ``cores``, ``instances`` and ``ram`` are still enforced, but the limit can only be changed globally via configuration. There are no per project or per user overrides possible. It can be enabled via ``[quota]/driver=nova.quota.UnifiedLimitsDriver``

subject: Update quota apis with keystone limits and usage

'}, {'number': 8, 'created': '2020-06-02 11:58:20.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/0773f776a88d8cc7493eb1dace4126350fc68b4a', 'message': "Update quota apis with keystone limits and usage

This makes use of the keystone APIs to get limits from Keystone when
showing the user the limits on their project.

Note we also change the default in_use amount from -1, which is what the
no op driver originally used, to 0, which matches what the db driver
typically returns for deprecated quota values, like floating ip limits.
This seems a more sane value to respond with, given we don't count the
usage for those values.

Future patches will look at proxying the quota update APIs to keystone.

blueprint unified-limits-nova

Change-Id: I933dc135a364b14ddadc8eee67b42d8e1278a9ae

commit_message:
Update quota apis with keystone limits and usage

This makes use of the keystone APIs to get limits from Keystone when
showing the user the limits on their project.

Note we also change the default in_use amount from -1, which is what the
no op driver originally used, to 0, which matches what the db driver
typically returns for deprecated quota values, like floating ip limits.
This seems a more sane value to respond with, given we don't count the
usage for those values.

blueprint unified-limits-nova

Change-Id: I933dc135a364b14ddadc8eee67b42d8e1278a9ae
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/99/713499/34 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from nova.limit import keystone as keystone_limit keystone_limits = keystone_limit.get_legacy_default_limits() if resource.name in keystone_limits: quotas[resource.name] = keystone_limits[resource.name] else: quotas[resource.name] = local_limits.get(resource.name, -1) local_limits = local_limit.get_local_limits() keystone_limits = keystone_limit.get_legacy_project_limits(project_id) project_quotas = {} for resource in resources.values(): if resource.name in keystone_limits: limit = keystone_limits[resource.name] else: limit = local_limits.get(resource.name, -1) project_quotas[resource.name] = {"limit": limit} k_in_use = keystone_limit.get_legacy_counts(context, project_id) for resource in resources.values(): usage_count = -1 if resource.name in local_in_use: usage_count = local_in_use[resource.name] if resource.name in k_in_use: usage_count = k_in_use[resource.name] project_quotas[resource.name]["in_use"] = usage_count return project_quotas
deleted_lines: quotas[resource.name] = local_limits.get(resource.name, -1) local_limits = self.get_class_quotas(context, resources, quota_class) local_in_use = {} quotas = {} for resource in resources.values(): quota = {"limit": local_limits.get(resource.name, -1)} if usages: quota["in_use"] = local_in_use.get(resource.name, -1) quotas[resource.name] = quota return quotas

subject: Add legacy limits and usage to placement unified limits

commit_message:
Add legacy limits and usage to placement unified limits

Before we can update the API to say what limits are set in keystone we
need to logic to pull that information from keystone.

blueprint unified-limits-nova

Change-Id: I322d5143f3088b04d1d990880b57afc9dc08af6c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/98/713498/34 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: LEGACY_LIMITS = { "servers": "instances", "class:VCPU": "cores", "class:MEMORY_MB": "ram", } resource_name = "class:%s" % resource_class resource_counts[resource_name] = usages.get(resource_class, 0) return LEGACY_LIMITS.get(new_name, new_name) def _convert_keys_to_legacy_name(new_dict): legacy = {} for new_name, old_name in LEGACY_LIMITS.items(): # defensive incase oslo or keystone doesn't give us an answer legacy[old_name] = new_dict.get(new_name) or 0 return legacy def get_legacy_default_limits(): new_limits = {} # TODO(johngarbutt): need oslo.limit API for this, it should do caching limit_utils = limit._EnforcerUtils() for new_name in LEGACY_LIMITS.keys(): max = limit_utils._get_registered_limit(new_name) new_limits[new_name] = max return _convert_keys_to_legacy_name(new_limits) def get_legacy_project_limits(project_id): new_limits = {} # TODO(johngarbutt): need oslo.limit API for this, it should do caching limit_utils = limit._EnforcerUtils() for new_name in LEGACY_LIMITS.keys(): try: proj_limit = limit_utils._get_limit(project_id, new_name) except limit._LimitNotFound: # If limit is not set, we don't allow use of this resource proj_limit = 0 new_limits[new_name] = proj_limit return _convert_keys_to_legacy_name(new_limits) def get_legacy_counts(context, project_id): resource_names = list(LEGACY_LIMITS.keys()) resource_names.sort() new_usage = _get_usage(context, project_id, resource_names) return _convert_keys_to_legacy_name(new_usage)
deleted_lines: resource_counts[resource_class] = usages.get(resource_class, 0) if new_name == "servers": return "instances" if new_name == "class:VCPU": return "cores" if new_name == "class:MEMORY_MB": return "ram" return new_name

commit_message:
Support volume re-image

This patch adds volume re-image API to enable the ability to
re-image a specific volume.

Implements: blueprint add-volume-re-image-api

Co-Authored-by: Rajat Dhasmana <rajatdhasmana@gmail.com>

Change-Id: I031aae50ee82198648f46c503bba04c6e231bbe5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/46/606346/35 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def reimage(self, context, vol_ref, image_id): image_meta = self.image_service.show(context, image_id) volume_utils.check_image_metadata(image_meta, vol_ref['size']) self.volume_rpcapi.reimage(context, vol_ref, image_id)

subject: Enforce resource limits using oslo.limit

'}, {'number': 4, 'created': '2018-11-02 18:04:47.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/15706149ee69d7d108df38c2d802d5e17f65aa9c', 'message': 'WIP: Integrating with unified limits

Alongside the existing quota API this change adds a new limits api that
makes an explicit distinction between:
* dynamic limits from unified limits (cores, ram, etc)
* countable db protection limits (keypairs, server_groups)
* api request db protection limits (metadata_items, injected_files)

The last two could be make the same if the caller was made responsible
for doing the counting. But that kinda defeats the object.

No attempt has been made to adopt context managers to help simplify the
recheck quota logic. It has simply been added alongside the existing
logic, inheriting the same good and bad points of the existing logic.

NOTE:
This uses my own hacked up oslo.limit lib to try and show what sort of
interface might work.

This is just a "sketch", no testing has been done. Just here to share
ideas and help agree a direction.

blueprint unified-limits-stein

Change-Id: If1df93400dcbcb1d3aac0ade80ae5ecf6ce38d11

Alongside the existing quota API this change adds a new limits api that
makes an explicit distinction between:
* instance limits from unified limits (server count, resources classes)
* countable db protection limits (keypairs, server_groups)
* api request db protection limits (metadata_items, injected_files)

The last two could be make the same if the caller was made responsible
for doing the counting. But that kinda defeats the object.

No attempt has been made to adopt context managers to help simplify the
recheck quota logic. It has simply been added alongside the existing
logic, inheriting the same good and bad points of the existing logic.

NOTE:
This uses my own hacked up oslo.limit lib to try and show what sort of
interface might work.
We assume the use of the placement counting logic here, and that all
migration of data that is needed has already been done, etc.

This is just a "sketch", no testing has been done. Just here to share
ideas and help agree a direction.

blueprint unified-limits-stein

'}, {'number': 12, 'created': '2019-11-25 17:57:39.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/2ee4a15307767a8637235996c4a26d6557dbf82e', 'message': "WIP: Enforce unified limits using oslo.limit

A new configuration option is added for operators to opt in to unified
limit enforcement. To opt in, you must set:

   [quota]
   use_unified_limits = True

When use_unified_limits is True, the existing quota enforcement is
hardcoded to use the NoopQuotaDriver. When it is False, all the new
unified limits enforcement doesn't apply. This means where you want to
apply both the existing quotas and unified limits, you simply ensure
that both existing quotas and unified limits are checked. The underlying
frameworks will ensure the configuration is respected.

Long term, subject to operator feedback, we hope to remove the existing
quota system, and leave only unified limits.
We assume the use of the placement counting logic here, and that all
migration of data that is needed has already been done.

Many existing quotas are not being moved to unified limits. These can be
grouped into two categories:

* api request based limits (metadata_items, injected files)
* db count based limits (keypairs, server_groups, server_group_members)

These limits are now only set via configuration, there is no API in
either Nova or Keystone that will influence the limits applied. In
addition, the limits are now global to all projects and users, i.e. we
loose the option to have per project overrides.

TODO: no consensus on this yet!
In addition, the above limits are also not rechecked following the DB
changes that are made to see if there was a race between the check and
DB call between different API workers. This is so we move towards a much
simpler system in the long term.

As such, existing quota enforcement will have one of the following calls
added after it:

* local_limit.enforce_api_limit
* local_limit.enforce_db_limit
* keystone_limit.enforce

blueprint unified-limits-nova

NOTE:
This uses my own hacked up oslo.limit lib to try and show what sort of
interface might work.
Depends-On: I294a922ea80af673291c991f07a4a203f25c289d

Change-Id: If1df93400dcbcb1d3aac0ade80ae5ecf6ce38d11

* db count based limits (keypairs, server_groups, server_group_members)

These limits are now only set via configuration, there is no API in
either Nova or Keystone that will influence the limits applied. In
addition, the limits are now global to all projects and users, i.e. we
loose the option to have per project overrides.

TODO: no consensus on this yet!
In addition, the above limits are also not rechecked following the DB
changes that are made to see if there was a race between the check and
DB call between different API workers. This is so we move towards a much
simpler system in the long term.

As such, existing quota enforcement will have one of the following calls
added after it:

* local_limit.enforce_api_limit
* local_limit.enforce_db_limit
* keystone_limit.enforce

blueprint unified-limits-nova

NOTE:
This uses my own hacked up oslo.limit lib to try and show what sort of
interface might work.
Depends-On: I294a922ea80af673291c991f07a4a203f25c289d

Change-Id: If1df93400dcbcb1d3aac0ade80ae5ecf6ce38d11
"}, {'number': 16, 'created': '2020-02-18 10:20:08.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/9c00eecfb54f0df3f94d5e48b7f3dfa647048cc6', 'message': "WIP: Enforce unified limits using oslo.limit

A new configuration option is added for operators to opt in to unified
limit enforcement. To opt in, you must set:

   [quota]
   use_unified_limits = True

When use_unified_limits is True, the existing quota enforcement is
hardcoded to use the NoopQuotaDriver. When it is False, all the new
unified limits enforcement doesn't apply. This means where you want to
apply both the existing quotas and unified limits, you simply ensure
that both existing quotas and unified limits are checked. The underlying
frameworks will ensure the configuration is respected.

Long term, subject to operator feedback, we hope to remove the existing
quota system, and leave only unified limits.
We assume the use of the placement counting logic here, and that all
migration of data that is needed has already been done.

Many existing quotas are not being moved to unified limits. These can be
grouped into two categories:

* api request based limits (metadata_items, injected files)
* db count based limits (keypairs, server_groups, server_group_members)

These limits are now only set via configuration, there is no API in
either Nova or Keystone that will influence the limits applied. In
addition, the limits are now global to all projects and users, i.e. we
loose the option to have per project overrides.

TODO: no consensus on this yet!
In addition, the above limits are also not rechecked following the DB
changes that are made to see if there was a race between the check and
DB call between different API workers. This is so we move towards a much
simpler system in the long term.

As such, existing quota enforcement will have one of the following calls
added after it:

* local_limit.enforce_api_limit
* local_limit.enforce_db_limit
* keystone_limit.enforce

blueprint unified-limits-nova

NOTE:
This uses my own hacked up oslo.limit lib to try and show what sort of
interface might work.
Depends-On: I294a922ea80af673291c991f07a4a203f25c289d

Change-Id: If1df93400dcbcb1d3aac0ade80ae5ecf6ce38d11

"}, {'number': 20, 'created': '2020-03-10 17:45:24.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/0c9826462d1d105ceece31af3fb32c48932eb5b1', 'message': "WIP: Enforce unified limits using oslo.limit

TODO: started to split up the previous large patch, still need:
* changes before this one to update the apis for the first set of limits
* changes after this one to update the apis to query and set limits in
  keystone, etc.
* nova_manage to export something for keystone manage, help with
  transition

A new configuration option is added for operators to opt in to unified
limit enforcement. To opt in, you must set:

   [quota]
   use_unified_limits = True

When use_unified_limits is True, the existing quota enforcement is
hardcoded to use the NoopQuotaDriver. When it is False, all the new
unified limits enforcement doesn't apply. This means where you want to
apply both the existing quotas and unified limits, you simply ensure
that both existing quotas and unified limits are checked. The underlying
frameworks will ensure the configuration is respected.

Long term, subject to operator feedback, we hope to remove the existing
quota system, and leave only unified limits.
We assume the use of the placement counting logic here, and that all
migration of data that is needed has already been done.

Many existing quotas are not being moved to unified limits. These can be
grouped into two categories:

* api request based limits (metadata_items, injected files)
* db count based limits (keypairs, server_groups, server_group_members)

These limits are now only set via configuration, there is no API in
either Nova or Keystone that will influence the limits applied. In
addition, the limits are now global to all projects and users, i.e. we
loose the option to have per project overrides.

TODO: no consensus on this yet!
In addition, the above limits are also not rechecked following the DB
changes that are made to see if there was a race between the check and
DB call between different API workers. This is so we move towards a much
simpler system in the long term.

As such, existing quota enforcement will have one of the following calls
added after it:

* local_limit.enforce_api_limit
* local_limit.enforce_db_limit
* keystone_limit.enforce

blueprint unified-limits-nova

Need to add oslo.limit into global requirements
Depends-On: I4380aaa7fbad005a1b5081c36afec30d58806580

Change-Id: If1df93400dcbcb1d3aac0ade80ae5ecf6ce38d11

"}, {'number': 23, 'created': '2020-03-16 17:49:41.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/d8f93fa5316e5760e8190661056d423728a69a7b', 'message': 'WIP: Enforce resource limits using oslo.limit

When use_unified_limits = True, we now enforce resource limits. This
includes: instances, ram, cores. It also works for any resource class
being requested via the flavor chosen, such as custom resource classes
relating to Ironic resources.

Follow on patches will update the APIs to accurately report the limits
being applied to instances, ram and cores.

TODO: been splitting the large patches, but still need to:
* changes after this one to update the apis to query and set limits in
  keystone, etc.
* nova_manage to export something for keystone manage, help with
  transition

blueprint unified-limits-nova

Change-Id: If1df93400dcbcb1d3aac0ade80ae5ecf6ce38d11
'}, {'number': 24, 'created': '2020-03-25 11:33:44.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/4a725a3f32b35c4f68fea535d80d57500a3db2fc', 'message': 'WIP: Enforce resource limits using oslo.limit

We now enforce limits on resources requested in the flavor.
This includes: instances, ram, cores. It also works for any resource
class being requested via the flavor chosen, such as custom resource
classes relating to Ironic resources.

Note because disk resources can be limited, we need to know if the
instance is boot from volume or not. This has meant adding extra code to
make sure we know that when enforcing the limits.

Follow on patches will update the APIs to accurately report the limits
being applied to instances, ram and cores.

blueprint unified-limits-nova

Change-Id: If1df93400dcbcb1d3aac0ade80ae5ecf6ce38d11

We now enforce limits on resources requested in the flavor.
This includes: instances, ram, cores. It also works for any resource
class being requested via the flavor chosen, such as custom resource
classes relating to Ironic resources.

Note because disk resources can be limited, we need to know if the
instance is boot from volume or not. This has meant adding extra code to
make sure we know that when enforcing the limits.

Follow on patches will update the APIs to accurately report the limits
being applied to instances, ram and cores.

commit_message:
Enforce resource limits using oslo.limit

We now enforce limits on resources requested in the flavor.
This includes: instances, ram, cores. It also works for any resource
class being requested via the flavor chosen, such as custom resource
classes relating to Ironic resources.

Note because disk resources can be limited, we need to know if the
instance is boot from volume or not. This has meant adding extra code to
make sure we know that when enforcing the limits.

Follow on patches will update the APIs to accurately report the limits
being applied to instances, ram and cores.

blueprint unified-limits-nova

Change-Id: If1df93400dcbcb1d3aac0ade80ae5ecf6ce38d11
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/80/615180/22 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from nova import limit limits.check_api_limit(injected_files=len(injected_files)) limits.check_api_limit(injected_file_path_bytes=max_path, injected_file_content_bytes=max_content) limits.check_api_limit(metadata_items=num_metadata) limits.check_static_limit(context, 'server_group_members', instance_group, additional_resource=1) limits.check_static_limit(context, 'server_group_members', instance_group, additional_resource=1)

subject: Tell oslo.limit how to count nova resources
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2020-03-16 17:49:41.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/64c33376afa65441df5ea0fadee08cd113ff4d10', 'message': "WIP: Tell oslo.limit how to count nova resources

A follow on patch will use this code to enforce the limits, this patch
provides integration with oslo.limit and a new internal nova API that is
able to enforce those limits.

The first part is providing a callback for olso.limit to be able to count
the resources being used. We only count resources grouped by project_id.

For counting servers, we make use of the instance mappings list in the
api database, just as the existing quota code does. While we do check to
ensure the queued for delete migration has been completed, we simply
error out if that is not the case, rather than attempting to fallback to
any other counting system. We hope one day we can count this in
placement using consumer records, or similar.

For counting all other resource usage, they must refer to some usage
relating to a resource class being consumed in placement. This is similar
to how the count with placement variant of the existing placement code
works today. This is not restricted to RAM and VCPU, it is open to any
resource class that is known to placement.

The second part is the enforcement method, that keeps a similar
signature to the existing enforce_num_instnaces call that is use to
check quotas using the legacy quota system.

From the flavor we extract the current resource usage. This is
considered the simplest first step that helps us deliver Ironic limits
alongside all the existing RAM and VCPU limits. At a later date, we
would ideally get passed a more complete view of what resources are
being requested from placement.

TODO: Currently the disk is always enforced, because boot from volume
isn't known at this point in the code?

NOTE: given the instance object doesn't exist when enforce is called, we
can't just pass the instance into here.

blueprint unified-limits-nova

Change-Id: I272b59b7bc8975bfd602640789f80d2d5f7ee698
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2020-03-24 17:53:59.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/18300f15fed19d74be65bc18e173778c0d1a74a3', 'message': "Tell oslo.limit how to count nova resources

A follow on patch will use this code to enforce the limits, this patch
provides integration with oslo.limit and a new internal nova API that is
able to enforce those limits.

The first part is providing a callback for olso.limit to be able to count
the resources being used. We only count resources grouped by project_id.

For counting servers, we make use of the instance mappings list in the
api database, just as the existing quota code does. While we do check to
ensure the queued for delete migration has been completed, we simply
error out if that is not the case, rather than attempting to fallback to
any other counting system. We hope one day we can count this in
placement using consumer records, or similar.

For counting all other resource usage, they must refer to some usage
relating to a resource class being consumed in placement. This is similar
to how the count with placement variant of the existing placement code
works today. This is not restricted to RAM and VCPU, it is open to any
resource class that is known to placement.

The second part is the enforcement method, that keeps a similar
signature to the existing enforce_num_instnaces call that is use to
check quotas using the legacy quota system.

From the flavor we extract the current resource usage. This is
considered the simplest first step that helps us deliver Ironic limits
alongside all the existing RAM and VCPU limits. At a later date, we
would ideally get passed a more complete view of what resources are
being requested from placement.

NOTE: given the instance object doesn't exist when enforce is called, we
can't just pass the instance into here.

blueprint unified-limits-nova

Change-Id: I272b59b7bc8975bfd602640789f80d2d5f7ee698
"}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2020-03-25 16:58:08.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/5f477d0c313e6b122194d0855994b63f9dd5db7e', 'message': "Tell oslo.limit how to count nova resources

the resources being used. We only count resources grouped by project_id.

For counting servers, we make use of the instance mappings list in the
api database, just as the existing quota code does. While we do check to
ensure the queued for delete migration has been completed, we simply
error out if that is not the case, rather than attempting to fallback to
any other counting system. We hope one day we can count this in
placement using consumer records, or similar.

For counting all other resource usage, they must refer to some usage
relating to a resource class being consumed in placement. This is similar
to how the count with placement variant of the existing placement code
works today. This is not restricted to RAM and VCPU, it is open to any
resource class that is known to placement.

The second part is the enforcement method, that keeps a similar
signature to the existing enforce_num_instnaces call that is use to
check quotas using the legacy quota system.

From the flavor we extract the current resource usage. This is
considered the simplest first step that helps us deliver Ironic limits
alongside all the existing RAM and VCPU limits. At a later date, we
would ideally get passed a more complete view of what resources are
being requested from placement.

NOTE: given the instance object doesn't exist when enforce is called, we
can't just pass the instance into here.

blueprint unified-limits-nova

Change-Id: I272b59b7bc8975bfd602640789f80d2d5f7ee698

able to enforce those limits.

The first part is providing a callback for oslo.limit to be able to count
the resources being used. We only count resources grouped by project_id.

For counting servers, we make use of the instance mappings list in the
api database, just as the existing quota code does. While we do check to
ensure the queued for delete migration has been completed, we simply
error out if that is not the case, rather than attempting to fallback to
any other counting system. We hope one day we can count this in

relating to a resource class being consumed in placement. This is similar
to how the count with placement variant of the existing placement code

The second part is the enforcement method, that keeps a similar

signature to the existing enforce_num_instnaces call that is use to
check quotas using the legacy quota system.

From the flavor we extract the current resource usage. This is
considered the simplest first step that helps us deliver Ironic limits
alongside all the existing RAM and VCPU limits. At a later date, we
would ideally get passed a more complete view of what resources are
being requested from placement.

NOTE: given the instance object doesn't exist when enforce is called, we
can't just pass the instance into here.

A [workarounds] option is also available for operators who need the
legacy quota usage behavior where VCPU = VCPU + PCPU.

blueprint unified-limits-nova

Change-Id: I272b59b7bc8975bfd602640789f80d2d5f7ee698
"}, {'number': 19, 'created': '2021-10-01 22:45:10.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/a22b6addcebc1d8b63ae9f89bc0a8f833e7af373', 'message': "Tell oslo.limit how to count nova resources

A follow on patch will use this code to enforce the limits, this patch
provides integration with oslo.limit and a new internal nova API that is
able to enforce those limits.

The first part is providing a callback for oslo.limit to be able to count
the resources being used. We only count resources grouped by project_id.

For counting servers, we make use of the instance mappings list in the
api database, just as the existing quota code does. While we do check to
ensure the queued for delete migration has been completed, we simply
error out if that is not the case, rather than attempting to fallback to
any other counting system. We hope one day we can count this in
placement using consumer records, or similar.

For counting all other resource usage, they must refer to some usage
relating to a resource class being consumed in placement. This is similar
to how the count with placement variant of the existing placement code
works today. This is not restricted to RAM and VCPU, it is open to any
resource class that is known to placement.

The second part is the enforcement method, that keeps a similar
signature to the existing enforce_num_instnaces call that is use to
check quotas using the legacy quota system.

From the flavor we extract the current resource usage. This is
considered the simplest first step that helps us deliver Ironic limits
alongside all the existing RAM and VCPU limits. At a later date, we
would ideally get passed a more complete view of what resources are
being requested from placement.

NOTE: given the instance object doesn't exist when enforce is called, we
can't just pass the instance into here.

A [workarounds] option is also available for operators who need the
legacy quota usage behavior where VCPU = VCPU + PCPU.

blueprint unified-limits-nova

Change-Id: I272b59b7bc8975bfd602640789f80d2d5f7ee698

For counting servers, we make use of the instance mappings list in the
api database, just as the existing quota code does. While we do check to
ensure the queued for delete migration has been completed, we simply
error out if that is not the case, rather than attempting to fallback to
any other counting system. We hope one day we can count this in
placement using consumer records, or similar.

For counting all other resource usage, they must refer to some usage
relating to a resource class being consumed in placement. This is similar
to how the count with placement variant of the existing placement code
works today. This is not restricted to RAM and VCPU, it is open to any
resource class that is known to placement.

The second part is the enforcement method, that keeps a similar
signature to the existing enforce_num_instnaces call that is use to
check quotas using the legacy quota system.

From the flavor we extract the current resource usage. This is
considered the simplest first step that helps us deliver Ironic limits
alongside all the existing RAM and VCPU limits. At a later date, we
would ideally get passed a more complete view of what resources are
being requested from placement.

NOTE: given the instance object doesn't exist when enforce is called, we
can't just pass the instance into here.

A [workarounds] option is also available for operators who need the
legacy quota usage behavior where VCPU = VCPU + PCPU.

blueprint unified-limits-nova

Change-Id: I272b59b7bc8975bfd602640789f80d2d5f7ee698

commit_message:
Tell oslo.limit how to count nova resources

A follow on patch will use this code to enforce the limits, this patch
provides integration with oslo.limit and a new internal nova API that is
able to enforce those limits.

The first part is providing a callback for oslo.limit to be able to count
the resources being used. We only count resources grouped by project_id.

For counting servers, we make use of the instance mappings list in the
api database, just as the existing quota code does. While we do check to
ensure the queued for delete migration has been completed, we simply
error out if that is not the case, rather than attempting to fallback to
any other counting system. We hope one day we can count this in
placement using consumer records, or similar.

For counting all other resource usage, they must refer to some usage
relating to a resource class being consumed in placement. This is similar
to how the count with placement variant of the existing placement code
works today. This is not restricted to RAM and VCPU, it is open to any
resource class that is known to placement.

The second part is the enforcement method, that keeps a similar
signature to the existing enforce_num_instnaces call that is use to
check quotas using the legacy quota system.

From the flavor we extract the current resource usage. This is
considered the simplest first step that helps us deliver Ironic limits
alongside all the existing RAM and VCPU limits. At a later date, we
would ideally get passed a more complete view of what resources are
being requested from placement.

NOTE: given the instance object doesn't exist when enforce is called, we
can't just pass the instance into here.

A [workarounds] option is also available for operators who need the
legacy quota usage behavior where VCPU = VCPU + PCPU.

blueprint unified-limits-nova

Change-Id: I272b59b7bc8975bfd602640789f80d2d5f7ee698

commit_message:
Fix request id mess on Cinder-API

This patch fixes multiple issues related to request ids:

- Duplicated request ID in logs
- Missing request id header in response
- Wrong request ID in response header when using noauth

The source of these issues is the fact that the request ID and the
request context are set too late, or not at all, in the paste filter
chain.

And the last bug is fixed as a freebie when the code in auth.py is
refactored to reduce code duplication on setting the cinder.context key
in the request's environment.

The patch fixes these issue by changing the filter chains to have the
request_id filter as the first filter, and using our own filter for it,
to ensure that the context is correctly set.

Not sure if values now defined in ENV_OVERWRITES are still necessary,
so the patch preserves current behavior.

Closes-Bug: #1960019
Closes-Bug: #1960020
Closes-Bug: #1960021
Closes-Bug: #1960329
Change-Id: Ide831a221a7561bbb7da193f0edb011f1989420e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/60/827860/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2020-03-12 17:41:16.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/b10943294a6901dcf00b71e10fe9cdd50131e0c9', 'message': 'WIP: Fix up quota classes APIs

Ensure the limit related APIs reflect the new reality of enforcing the
API and DB limits based on configuration only.

commit_message:
Update quota sets APIs

Ensure the limit related APIs reflect the new reality of enforcing the
API and DB limits based on keystone only.

For now we skip all updates to the DB, as none mean anything to the new
code, as we only look at keystone now.

Note: this will need to be updated again once we add limits for
cores, ram, instances, etc.

blueprint unified-limits-nova

Change-Id: I5ef968395b4bdc6f190e239a19a723316b1d5baf

commit_message:
Add missing microversion entry for 3.67

Change I3729cbe1902ab4dc335451d13ed921ec236fb8fd merged
implementing microversion 3.67 but missed an entry in
the microversions.py file.
This patch addresses the same.

Change-Id: Ifd30ee86e657ddda9746eddcd080557520b1d468

commit_message:
Update limit APIs

Ensure the limit related APIs reflect the new reality of enforcing the
API and DB limits based on keystone. Do this by implementing the
get_project_quotas and get_user_quotas methods.

This still leaves get_settable_quotas and get_defaults that are needed to
fix the quota sets APIs.

Note: this will need to be updated again once we add limits for
cores, ram, instances, etc.

blueprint unified-limits-nova

Change-Id: I3c4c29740e6275449887c4136d2467eade04fb06
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/07/712707/15 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from nova import objects self.flags(server_groups=12, group='quota') @mock.patch.object(objects.InstanceGroupList, "get_counts") def test_index_v21(self, mock_count): mock_count.return_value = {'project': {'server_groups': 9}} 'maxImageMeta': 128, 'maxPersonality': 5, 'maxPersonalitySize': 10240, 'maxServerGroupMembers': 10, 'maxServerGroups': 12, 'maxServerMeta': 128, 'maxTotalKeypairs': 100, 'totalServerGroupsUsed': 9, @mock.patch.object(objects.InstanceGroupList, "get_counts") def test_index_v275(self, mock_count): mock_count.return_value = {'project': {'server_groups': 9}} 'maxServerGroupMembers': 10, 'maxServerGroups': 12, 'maxServerMeta': 128, 'maxTotalKeypairs': 100, 'totalServerGroupsUsed': 9,

subject: Update quota_class APIs for db and api limits

that use things like resource_class, etc.

commit_message:
Update quota_class APIs for db and api limits

Implement a unified limits specific version of get_class_quotas as used
by the quota_class API. This simply returns the limits defined in
keystone that are now enforced when you enable unified limits.

Note: this will need to be updated again once we add limits to things
that use things like resource_class, etc.

blueprint unified-limits-nova

Change-Id: If9901662d30d15da13303a3da051e1b9fded72c0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/43/712143/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from nova.limit import local as local_limit def get_class_quotas(self, context, resources, quota_class): """Given a list of resources, retrieve the quotas for the given quota class. :param context: The request context, for access checks. :param resources: A dictionary of the registered resources. :param quota_class: The name of the quota class to return quotas for. """ local_limits = local_limit.get_local_limits() # Default to unlimited, as per no-op for everything that isn't # a local limit quotas = {} for resource in resources.values(): quotas[resource.name] = local_limits.get(resource.name, {"limit": -1})["limit"] return quotas

subject: core: Gracefully handle missing config option

may in some circumstances raise an exception due to missing

Handle this situation gracefully.

Related-Bug: #1951462

commit_message:
core: Gracefully handle missing config option

The ``get_os_codename_package`` function will be called by all
charms.  The newly added call to the ``configure_source`` method
may in some circumstances raise an exception due to missing
source configuration option.

Handle this situation gracefully.

Related-Bug: #1951462
Change-Id: I2bb9c2561b89fea366bd7b7f6a10c3140ce09000
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/charms.openstack refs/changes/74/831074/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: self.configure_source.side_effect = KeyError self.configure_source.side_effect = None

subject: Enforce api and db limits
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2020-03-10 17:45:24.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/f051e44dda5a04c51121faa42d19df25b4c0e697', 'message': 'WIP: Enforce api and db limits

When using unified limits, we add enforcement of those limits on all
related API calls. Note: we do not yet correctly report the configured
limits to users via the quota APIs, that is in a future patch.

Note the unified limits calls are made alongside the existing legacy
quota calls. The old quota calls will be handed by the quota engine
driver, that is basically a no-op. This is to make it easier to remove
the legacy code paths in the future.

Note, to ease integration, the exceptions raised match those raised by
the existing exception code, regardless of the strange nature of the
information passed back to the caller via an exception. The user of the
API will see the same return values, no matter which code is enabled to
enforce the limits.

TODO: need to double check test coverage here.

blueprint unified-limits-nova

Change-Id: I36e82a17579158063396d7e55b495ccff4959ceb

'}, {'number': 5, 'created': '2020-03-12 16:15:52.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/cebe96c57171bdba0950d207b6e8a59cc231a492', 'message': 'Enforce api and db limits

When using unified limits, we add enforcement of those limits on all
related API calls. Note: we do not yet correctly report the configured
limits to users via the quota APIs, that is in a future patch.

Note the unified limits calls are made alongside the existing legacy
quota calls. The old quota calls will be handed by the quota engine
driver, that is basically a no-op. This is to make it easier to remove
the legacy code paths in the future.

Note, to ease integration, the exceptions raised match those raised by
the existing exception code, regardless of the strange nature of the
information passed back to the caller via an exception. The user of the
API will see the same return values, no matter which code is enabled to
enforce the limits.

blueprint unified-limits-nova

Change-Id: I36e82a17579158063396d7e55b495ccff4959ceb

'}, {'number': 15, 'created': '2021-08-29 03:18:18.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/d9ec491759d019f640775ae87a77fb65e65c8c39', 'message': 'Enforce api and db limits

When using unified limits, we add enforcement of those limits on all
related API calls. Note: we do not yet correctly report the configured
limits to users via the quota APIs, that is in a future patch.

Note the unified limits calls are made alongside the existing legacy
quota calls. The old quota calls will be handed by the quota engine
driver, that is basically a no-op. This is to make it easier to remove
the legacy code paths in the future.

Note, over quota exceptions raised with unified limits use the standard
(improved) exception message as those raised by oslo.limit. They
however do use the existing exception code to ease integration. The
user of the API will see the same return codes, no matter which code is
enabled to enforce the limits.

blueprint unified-limits-nova

Change-Id: I36e82a17579158063396d7e55b495ccff4959ceb

commit_message:
Enforce api and db limits

When using unified limits, we add enforcement of those limits on all
related API calls. Note: we do not yet correctly report the configured
limits to users via the quota APIs, that is in a future patch.

Note the unified limits calls are made alongside the existing legacy
quota calls. The old quota calls will be handed by the quota engine
driver, that is basically a no-op. This is to make it easier to remove
the legacy code paths in the future.

Note, over quota exceptions raised with unified limits use the standard
(improved) exception message as those raised by oslo.limit. They
however do use the existing exception code to ease integration. The
user of the API will see the same return codes, no matter which code is
enabled to enforce the limits.

Finally, this also adds test coverage where it was missing. Coverage
for "quota recheck" behavior in KeypairAPI is added where all other
KeypairAPI testing is located. Duplicate coverage is removed from
nova/api/openstack/compute/test_keypairs.py at the same time.

blueprint unified-limits-nova

Change-Id: I36e82a17579158063396d7e55b495ccff4959ceb

'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2022-01-21 21:50:55.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/c0dc932848148bc1a3eb267c090be9095179f037', 'message': 'expirer: Only try to delete containers if it might succeed

Which is to say, if all the tasks we saw in the container were actually

'}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2022-01-21 22:50:04.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/3ebe8619019505397a5e0b8b5ce529b6313b1b25', 'message': 'expirer: Only try to delete containers if it might succeed

Which is to say, if all the tasks we saw in the container were actually

Change-Id: I8c3f78d1d1850ab501180f884f81f84552617fb7
'}, {'number': 4, 'created': '2022-02-11 00:08:01.000000000', 'files': ['test/unit/obj/test_expirer.py', 'swift/obj/expirer.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/229065d7810c29e5cda07667369969e347785561', 'message': "expirer: Only try to delete empty containers

Currently, the object-expirer is a little delete-happy -- after a
container gets processed, an attempt is always made to delete it,
even if we know it will fail with a 409 because either

    * we found items that this worker won't process (see the
      process/processes config options) or

    * we encountered failures processing items and thus didn't
      pop all the records off the queue that we *could* process.

The failed DELETE has downsides such as

    * adding unnecessary load to the container servers (though
      the 409 can hopefully be serviced fairly quickly) and

    * evicting container info and listing shard ranges from
      memcache, which

    * can further load the container-servers (if the expiry queues
      have gotten large enough to shard), as all the expirers
      doing listings now have to go fetch shard ranges directly
      from the DB.

Now, only attempt to delete an expiry container if it appears to be
empty. In any reasonably-sized cluster, we expect dozens to hundreds of
concurrent expirers to be processing the expiry queues. Seeing the
container empty is the most reliable signal that the delete is expected
to succeed.

Change-Id: I8c3f78d1d1850ab501180f884f81f84552617fb7
"}]
commit_message:
expirer: Only try to delete empty containers

Currently, the object-expirer is a little delete-happy -- after a
container gets processed, an attempt is always made to delete it,
even if we know it will fail with a 409 because either

    * we found items that this worker won't process (see the
      process/processes config options) or

    * we encountered failures processing items and thus didn't
      pop all the records off the queue that we *could* process.

The failed DELETE has downsides such as

    * adding unnecessary load to the container servers (though
      the 409 can hopefully be serviced fairly quickly) and

    * evicting container info and listing shard ranges from
      memcache, which

    * can further load the container-servers (if the expiry queues
      have gotten large enough to shard), as all the expirers
      doing listings now have to go fetch shard ranges directly
      from the DB.

Now, only attempt to delete an expiry container if it appears to be
empty. In any reasonably-sized cluster, we expect dozens to hundreds of
concurrent expirers to be processing the expiry queues. Seeing the
container empty is the most reliable signal that the delete is expected
to succeed.

Change-Id: I8c3f78d1d1850ab501180f884f81f84552617fb7

commit_message:
Modify remaining APIs as per RBAC new guidelines

As per the RBAC new direction, we will allow
project resources operation to be performed by
the project scoped token only and system user will
be allowed to perform system level operation only
not project resources specific.

Details about new direction can be found in community-wide
goal
- https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/consistent-and-secure-rbac.html

This commit modify remaining APIs as per the new guidelines.

Also, allow all project admin to list the other project limits. This is
what we allowed in legacy policy and until we have domain admin or other
way to list other project resources/info, we will keep that behaviour.

Also modifying and adding tests for four cases:
1. enforce_scope=False + legacy rule (current default policies)
2. enforce_scope=False + No legacy rule
3. enforce_scope=True + legacy rule
4. enforce_scope=True + no legacy rule (end goal of new RBAC)

Partial implement blueprint policy-defaults-refresh-2

Change-Id: I006d47aa2f4678a06c78057bcf407302abbe4907

commit_message:
Release final python-senlinclient for Yoga

This is a release for python-senlinclient to get any merged but unreleased
changes out prior to the client lib freeze for Yoga going into effect.

If the team is ready to proceed, please leave a +1 to acknowledge this
release and we will process right away. If the team is working on any
final merges, leave a -1 with some detail on the status and update the
patch with the new commit hash to use when ready.

Patches with no response will be merged by Friday, February 25th.

$ git log --oneline --no-merges 2.3.0..9fc2edc
6b78b4a Add Python3 yoga unit tests
960d3a9 Update master for stable/xena
7cb1233 Use py3 as the default runtime for tox
d0b16e5 Add Python3 xena unit tests
46ffa06 Update master for stable/wallaby

Signed-off-by: Elod Illes <elod.illes@est.tech>
Change-Id: I3286783ae76578e8f17828e3a93f40a77945c3d3

commit_message:
Server actions APIs scoped to project scope

As per the RBAC new direction, we will allow
project resources operation to be performed by
the project scoped token only and system user will
be allowed to perform system level operation only
not project resources specific.

Details about new direction can be found in community-wide
goal
- https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/consistent-and-secure-rbac.html

This commit modify the server action APIs to be scoped
to project scope.

Fix the shelve-offload policy to pass the instance project
id as target.

Also modifying and adding tests for four cases:
1. enforce_scope=False + legacy rule (current default policies)
2. enforce_scope=False + No legacy rule
3. enforce_scope=True + legacy rule
4. enforce_scope=True + no legacy rule (end goal of new RBAC)

Partial implement blueprint policy-defaults-refresh-2

Change-Id: I5293e9aa9cb3b48f97a5a2cf272939ada1aea2db

commit_message:
Fix functional CI job

The glanceclient-dsvm-functional job is currently running unit
tests, whereas it should be running the functional tests.  Fixed
by honoring the path in .stestr.conf like other trees.

Also removed tox.ini from the list of irrelevant-files for this
job, because as it turns out, it is relevant.

Change-Id: I59773caa00ff0dfc970c0e4d45aa5d8ae006b1c6

commit_message:
Update qcow test to use qcow2 instead

qemu-img package for Centos 8 doesn't support qcow disk format anymore,
due to this, tests using qcow are failing with
`Unknown file format 'qcow'`.
This patch updates the qcow tests for qcow2 instead.

Closes-Bug: #1946457

Change-Id: If488ae4299a6cab521eec9c5e9ce4f29f94057e1
(cherry picked from commit 947e541fc0f7c0fc2b759898ab8b9401d152f3d0)

commit_message:
Mock tenacity in gluster driver unit tests

We're going into a long wait loop when the retrying
logic kicks in in some unit tests:

manila.tests.share.drivers.glusterfs.test_common.GlusterManagerTestCase.test_set_vol_option_error_1                                                        511.046
manila.tests.share.drivers.glusterfs.test_common.GlusterManagerTestCase.test_set_vol_option_error_2                                                        511.040

TrivialFix

Change-Id: I9eafbfe0cb806d05525a3b17c43d92f0f5fbfac1

commit_message:
[ceph-mon] Change configmap names to be based on release names

This change makes the ceph-mon configmap names dynamic based on
release name to match how the ceph-osd chart is naming configmaps.
The new ceph-mon post-apply job needs this in some cases in order
not to have conflicting configmap names in separate releases.

Change-Id: Id26d0a8310ccff80a608e25d2b0a74a41f9e6a55

commit_message:
Add debug log for scheduler weight calculation

We have all the weighers enabled by default and each can have its own
multiplier making the final compute node order calculation pretty
complex. This patch adds some debug logging that helps understanding how
the final ordering was reached.

Change-Id: I7606d6eb3e08548c1df9dc245ab39cced7de1fb5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/32/817632/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from oslo_log import log as logging LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) LOG.debug( "%s: raw weights %s", weigher.__class__.__name__, {(obj.obj.host, obj.obj.nodename): weight for obj, weight in zip(weighed_objs, weights)} ) weights = list( normalize( weights, minval=weigher.minval, maxval=weigher.maxval)) LOG.debug( "%s: normalized weights %s", weigher.__class__.__name__, {(obj.obj.host, obj.obj.nodename): weight for obj, weight in zip(weighed_objs, weights)} ) log_data = {} multiplier = weigher.weight_multiplier(obj.obj) weigher_score = multiplier * weight obj.weight += weigher_score log_data[(obj.obj.host, obj.obj.nodename)] = ( f"{multiplier} * {weight}") LOG.debug( "%s: score (multiplier * weight) %s", weigher.__class__.__name__, {name: log for name, log in log_data.items()} )
deleted_lines: weights = normalize(weights, minval=weigher.minval, maxval=weigher.maxval) obj.weight += weigher.weight_multiplier(obj.obj) * weight

commit_message:
Log which instance event was timed out

Nova compute logs what external events it waits for and logs if timeout
happens but it is not easy to figure out which even are timed out if
nova waits for multiple events, i.e.: there are multiple ports to be
plugged.

This patch moves the warning log into wait_for_instance_event itself and
extends the log with the name of the event nova waited for when the
timeout happens.

Change-Id: I91c42af8226dc8607d86c52413924351ba0586ac

subject: Get ports directly instead of via loop
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2021-09-15 15:43:07.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/horizon/commit/51509d5ee03c7512b583a9af17ea2a2cb4d274ee', 'message': 'Get ports directly instead of via loop

of the form code in `project/instances/attach_interface` loops through
the available networks in the project and requests a list of ports for

time for a Neutron API call) where N is the number of networks.

This change re-implements this particular part and uses one call to
the Neutron API to get the list of all ports and filters this list.

smaller.

commit_message:
Get ports directly instead of via loop

In order to get a list of available ports, the current implementation
of the form code in `project/instances/attach_interface` loops through
the available networks in the project and requests a list of ports for
each via the Neutron API. This implementation is O(N) in time with a
large prefactor (the time for a Neutron API call) where N is the
number of networks.

Instead of calling the Neutron API for each network this change uses
one call to the Neutron API to get the list of ports on all networks
and filters this list via a list comprehension. While this
implementation is still O(N) the prefactor is significantly smaller.

Closes-Bug: #1943639
Change-Id: I8fd32c3aad22d8ef7f57201f5144f6b2e357ef10
Signed-off-by: Nicolas Bock <nicolas.bock@canonical.com>

commit_message:
Use neutron client for server.addresses

The server.addresses (/servers/{server_id}/ips)
endpoint can contain stale data causing attribute
lookups to fail.

This change replaces the use of server.addresses
and instead uses the neutron client to list ports
with 'device_id' matching the server id.

Story: 2008632
Task: 41843
Related: RHBZ#1902230
Change-Id: I1b9293041f2ad92eac0e9bc9646e7b2d7c6f7fd0
(cherry picked from commit 45750c603ac9965afd5b4e53ecff65977b887b95)

subject: Add logic to enforce local api and db limits
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2020-03-10 17:45:24.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/3fd6871accfd5ddfba2de776a15ffde6e835f320', 'message': "Add logic to enforce local api and db limits

Future patches will make use of this logic, and actually enforce the
limits. This patch just adds the infrastructure to allow for the
enforcement of the limits.

We are not moving all existing quotas to be managed via Keystone's
unified limits. Many of the quotas that we previously allowed to be
overridden via the database, will now only be set via Nova
configuration.

These limits are all about preventing excessive load on the API and
database and have little to do with resource usage. As discussed over
several years at operators meetups, all operators seemed happy to
simplify the system by only setting these limits via configuration.

Local limits include things that just limit items in an API request:
* metadata_items
* injected_files
* injected_file_content_bytes
* injected_file_path_bytes

Local limits also include things that are stored in the database:
* key_pairs
* server_groups
* server_group_members

Note that each of the above are counted via a different scope. This new
code ensures that key_pairs are counted per user, server_groups are
counted per project and server_group_members are counted per
server_group.

Note: Previously server_group_member were counted per user inside each
server_group, which has proved very confusing, as adding more users into
a project increases the maximum size of allowed for a server_group.

blueprint unified-limits-nova

Change-Id: I0b6f4d29aaee1d71541a95cbecfd0708aac325d2

"}, {'number': 13, 'created': '2021-08-29 03:18:18.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/12d0af9fba68f28f3024c3bd8dc1154c95892636', 'message': 'Add logic to enforce local api and db limits

Local API and DB limits are limits on resources that are counted either
as an API request parameter (example: server metadata items) or as
records in the database (example: server key pairs).

Future patches will make use of this logic, and actually enforce the
limits. This patch just adds the infrastructure to allow for the
enforcement of the limits.

To stop confusion between injected_file_path_length and
injected_file_path_bytes, the configuration option has been changed to
match the name used the API. Configuration backwards compatibility is
maintained using the deprecated options list.

We are moving all existing quotas to be managed via Keystone's
unified limits.

These local limits are all about preventing excessive load on the API
and database and have little to do with resource usage. These limits
are represented by keystone registered limits only, accordingly.

Local limits include things that just limit items in an API request:
* metadata_items
* injected_files
* injected_file_content_bytes
* injected_file_path_bytes

Local limits also include things that are stored in the database:
* key_pairs
* server_groups
* server_group_members

Some resource names have been changed to prepend a prefix of "server_"
in order to disambiguate them from other potential unified limits in
keystone:

* metadata_items => server_metadata_items
* injected_files => server_injected_files
* injected_file_content_bytes => server_injected_file_content_bytes
* injected_file_path_bytes => server_injected_file_path_bytes
* key_pairs => server_key_pairs

Note that each of the above are counted via a different scope. This new
code ensures that key_pairs are counted per user, server_groups are
counted per project and server_group_members are counted per
server_group.

Note: Previously server_group_member were counted per user inside each
server_group, which has proved very confusing, as adding more users into
a project increases the maximum size of allowed for a server_group.

blueprint unified-limits-nova

Change-Id: I0b6f4d29aaee1d71541a95cbecfd0708aac325d2

'}, {'number': 15, 'created': '2021-09-16 03:39:56.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/b7e0b58f6390bc0c220c9642e7bf0c4b1e213a10', 'message': 'Add logic to enforce local api and db limits

Local API and DB limits are limits on resources that are counted either
as an API request parameter (example: server metadata items) or as
records in the database (example: server key pairs).

Future patches will make use of this logic, and actually enforce the
limits. This patch just adds the infrastructure to allow for the
enforcement of the limits.

We are moving all existing quotas to be managed via Keystone's
unified limits.

To stop confusion between injected_file_path_length and
injected_file_path_bytes, the unified limit in Keystone will use the
latter name to match the name used the API.

These local limits are all about preventing excessive load on the API
and database and have little to do with resource usage. These limits
are represented by keystone registered limits only, accordingly.

Local limits include things that just limit items in an API request:
* metadata_items
* injected_files
* injected_file_content_bytes
* injected_file_path_bytes

Local limits also include things that are stored in the database:
* key_pairs
* server_groups
* server_group_members

Some resource names have been changed to prepend a prefix of "server_"
in order to disambiguate them from other potential unified limits in
keystone:

* metadata_items => server_metadata_items
* injected_files => server_injected_files
* injected_file_content_bytes => server_injected_file_content_bytes
* injected_file_path_bytes => server_injected_file_path_bytes
* key_pairs => server_key_pairs

Note that each of the above are counted via a different scope. This new
code ensures that key_pairs are counted per user, server_groups are
counted per project and server_group_members are counted per
server_group.

Note: Previously server_group_member were counted per user inside each
server_group, which has proved very confusing, as adding more users into
a project increases the maximum size of allowed for a server_group.

blueprint unified-limits-nova

Change-Id: I0b6f4d29aaee1d71541a95cbecfd0708aac325d2

Note that each of the above are counted via a different scope. This new
code ensures that key_pairs are counted per user, server_groups are
counted per project and server_group_members are counted per
server_group.

Note: Previously server_group_member were counted per user inside each
server_group, which has proved very confusing, as adding more users into
a project increases the maximum size of allowed for a server_group.

blueprint unified-limits-nova

commit_message:
Add logic to enforce local api and db limits

Local API and DB limits are limits on resources that are counted either
as an API request parameter (example: server metadata items) or as
records in the database (example: server key pairs).

Future patches will make use of this logic, and actually enforce the
limits. This patch just adds the infrastructure to allow for the
enforcement of the limits.

We are moving all existing quotas to be managed via Keystone's
unified limits.

To stop confusion between injected_file_path_length and
injected_file_path_bytes, the unified limit in Keystone will use the
latter name to match the name used the API.

These local limits are all about preventing excessive load on the API
and database and have little to do with resource usage. These limits
are represented by keystone registered limits only, accordingly.

Local limits include things that just limit items in an API request:
* metadata_items
* injected_files
* injected_file_content_bytes
* injected_file_path_bytes

Local limits also include things that are stored in the database:
* key_pairs
* server_groups
* server_group_members

Some resource names have been changed to prepend a prefix of "server_"
in order to disambiguate them from other potential unified limits in
keystone:

* metadata_items => server_metadata_items
* injected_files => server_injected_files
* injected_file_content_bytes => server_injected_file_content_bytes
* injected_file_path_bytes => server_injected_file_path_bytes
* key_pairs => server_key_pairs

Note that each of the above are counted via a different scope. This new
code ensures that key_pairs are counted per user, server_groups are
counted per project and server_group_members are counted per
server_group.

Note: Previously server_group_member were counted per user inside each
server_group, which has proved very confusing, as adding more users into
a project increases the maximum size of allowed for a server_group.

blueprint unified-limits-nova

Change-Id: I0b6f4d29aaee1d71541a95cbecfd0708aac325d2

commit_message:
Manage async_pendings priority per containers

If, for any reasons (e.g.: big unsharded container), a container starts to
refuse all updates from object-servers, a lot of async_pendings will be
created on devices. All these async_pendings will rarely succeed,
slowing down the entire object-updater daemon. The issue is that
async_pendings not related to this problematic container will get treated
occasionaly, because they are lost in the crowd.

The fix is to change the path so that async_pendings are created in a
directory per container(-shard). The patch also allow to give a
time-limit and error-limit per container(-shard) so that a problematic
containers does not consume all the time of the object-updater.

The directories are all processed in parallels, one async-pending
per directory at a time, up to the concurrency limit. The goal is to avoid
spawning all the concurrency on a single container that is already in
trouble and have a many async-pendings on disk.

Failures and time limit are not enforced on legacy suffix directories.

Change-Id: I1f323e0086baea1387b2e6c70b808bc7e137f4da

commit_message:
Release final ironic-lib for Yoga

This proposed a release for ironic-lib to get any final merged changes
out prior to the lib freeze for Yoga going into effect.

If the team is ready to proceed, please leave a +1 to acknowledge this
release and we will process right away. If the team is working on any
final merges, leave a -1 with some detail on the status and update the
patch with the new commit hash to use when ready.

Patches with no response will be merged by Friday, February 18.

Signed-off-by: Daniel Bengtsson <dbengt@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I393721dd1a06d094391a257b12685e60e2d2ff7c

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2022-02-25 07:55:52.000000000', 'files': ['nova/conf/compute.py', 'nova/tests/unit/compute/test_compute_mgr.py', 'nova/tests/unit/objects/test_objects.py', 'nova/exception.py', 'nova/tests/unit/compute/test_compute.py', 'nova/compute/manager.py', 'nova/tests/unit/compute/test_api.py', 'nova/objects/external_event.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/dc20d8a23b7a5bf90fd7b6f0b629aae2b3f7f2d4', 'message': 'Add support for volume backed server rebuild

This patch adds the plumbing for rebuilding a volume backed
instance. This functionality will be enabled in a subsequent patch
which adds a new microversion and the external support for requesting
it.
The flow of the operation is as follows:

1) Detach the volume
2) Create an empty attachment
3) Request cinder to reimage the volume
4) Wait for cinder to notify success to nova (via external events)
5) Update and complete the attachment

Related blueprint volume-backed-server-rebuild

Change-Id: Ie1bbaa36bfd18b3c115c058f7e17001abe803f38

commit_message:
Add support for volume backed server rebuild

This patch adds the plumbing for rebuilding a volume backed
instance. This functionality will be enabled in a subsequent patch
which adds a new microversion and the external support for requesting
it.
The flow of the operation is as follows:

1) Detach the volume
2) Create an empty attachment
3) Request cinder to reimage the volume
4) Wait for cinder to notify success to nova (via external events)
5) Update and complete the attachment

Related blueprint volume-backed-server-rebuild
Change-Id: I0d889691de1af6875603a9f0f174590229e7be18

Change-Id: Ie1bbaa36bfd18b3c115c058f7e17001abe803f38

commit_message:
Fix v2 API dataframes get policy check

oslo.policy expects the key project_id, not tenant_id anymore. This was
causing the GET /v2/dataframes policy check to fail:

    $ openstack --rating-api-version 2 rating dataframes get
    {"message": "You are not authorized to perform this action"} (HTTP 403)

In the v1 API, the storage:list_data_frames operation was not affected
because it uses project_id.

Change-Id: Ie4aa6a21e3829223aab0f91d809e311e0f0318cb
Story: 2009879
Task: 44618

commit_message:
Add a Note Under Install and configure Section in documentation

This patch adds a note to use keystone port 5000 while configuring
horizon for all distros like ubuntu/debian/rdo/obs under the install
and configure section. Right now if a user tries to set up an OpenStack
env. manually using documentation [1], [2] leads to some confusion
because keystone documents suggest creating keystone endpoint at
http://controller:5000/v3/ rather than http://controller/v3/ while
horizon document consider keystone doesn't run at 5000 port updated
by [3].

Closes-Bug: #1910476
Closes-Bug: #1926096
Closes-Bug: #1950919
Closes-Bug: #1956437
Closes-Bug: #1892279
Closes-Bug: #1903320
Change-Id: I18d0d2105ea54ba02f8979ab7a15a75a0425b8c7

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/keystone/latest/install/keystone-install-ubuntu.html#install-and-configure-components
[2] https://docs.openstack.org/horizon/latest/install/install-ubuntu.html#install-and-configure-components
[3] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/horizon/+/697406

Change-Id: I537a963c9d955b8d7e21f0d05b0197588907419e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/54/825254/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. note:: In case your keystone run at 5000 port then you would mentioned keystone port here as well i.e. OPENSTACK_KEYSTONE_URL = "http://%s:5000/identity/v3" % OPENSTACK_HOST

subject: Slurp constraints.txt separately for each host in a batch
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2022-02-23 08:54:01.000000000', 'files': ['tasks/python_venv_install.yml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ansible-role-python_venv_build/commit/aac3b6f7725ccb61d65cb1125ce98f8748f26ed3', 'message': "Slurp constraints.txt separately for each host in a batch

Currently playbook slurps constraints.txt valid for a first host in a
batch and then uses it for each other host.

It saves time but batch may consists of hosts with different operating
systems or even OSA versions and current mechanism doesn't take this
into account.

In my opinion we should slurp constraints.txt separately for each host.

Change-Id: I9ba1d342af13e9c923151f735940bda29bf1b262
(cherry picked from commit 28f89b80a8fbac5018638d512978eec210269649)
"}]
commit_message:
Slurp constraints.txt separately for each host in a batch

Currently playbook slurps constraints.txt valid for a first host in a
batch and then uses it for each other host.

It saves time but batch may consists of hosts with different operating
systems or even OSA versions and current mechanism doesn't take this
into account.

In my opinion we should slurp constraints.txt separately for each host.

Change-Id: I9ba1d342af13e9c923151f735940bda29bf1b262
(cherry picked from commit 28f89b80a8fbac5018638d512978eec210269649)

commit_message:
setup.cfg: Replace dashes by underscores

Since setuptools v54.1.0[1], the parmeters with dash have been
deprecated in favor of the new parameters with underscore.

This change updates the parameters accordingly to avoid the warnings
like the example below.

  UserWarning: Usage of dash-separated 'description-file' will not be
  supported in future versions. Please use the underscore name
  'description_file' instead

[1] https://github.com/pypa/setuptools/commit/a2e9ae4cb

Change-Id: I3980fbc53ce4b954aff5e98087897ea94e50e4fc

commit_message:
Fix bindep for current rpm based distributions

python-devel is no longer available in current RPM based distributions.
This was tested with centos7, rhel7, rhel8, fedora35.

Change-Id: I4a2e6886af6d6862f25957e7bb206a5fc9664d90
